With a projected rotational velocity of 240 km/s, it spins at 88.5% of its breakup velocity. As a result, the star’s shape has been distorted into an oblate spheroid and its equatorial radius is about 20% larger than its radius at the poles. The radius at the equator is 2.858 solar radii and the polar radius is 2.388 solar radii.

Rasalhague is an example of a phenomenon known as gravity darkening. Due to its fast rotation and flattened shape, the surface gravity is higher at the poles than at the equator because the poles are closer to the centre of mass. For the same reason, the temperature is also higher at the poles (9,384 K) than at the equator (7,569 K), as is luminosity.

The star’s axis of rotation is inclined at 87.7° ± 0.4° to our line of sight, which means that we see Rasalhague almost exactly equator-on. The bolometric luminosity at this angle is 25.6 solar luminosities, but the star’s true luminosity is believed to be around 31.3 solar luminosities.

fields.name: Sirius
fields.description:
Sirius is the brightest star in the night sky and one of the nearest star systems to Earth. It has an apparent magnitude of -1.46 and lies at a distance of only 8.6 light years from the Sun. It is also known as the Dog Star, in reference to its position as the luminary of the constellation Canis Major, the Greater Dog. Sirius is a binary star system composed of Sirius A, a white main-sequence star of spectral type A0mA1 Va, and Sirius B, a white dwarf with the stellar classification DA2. Nicknamed The Pup, Sirius B is the nearest known white dwarf to the Sun.

Sirius A and Sirius B orbit each other every 50 years at a distance between 8.2 and 31.5 astronomical units, which translates into an angular separation between 3 and 11 arcseconds. At periastron (the closest approach), the two stars can only be resolved in a 12-inch or larger telescope. As they have been moving away from each other since the last periastron in 1994, Sirius A and Sirius B are easier to resolve. The average separation between the two stars is about 20 astronomical units, which is roughly equal to the distance between the Sun and Uranus. The stars have an elliptical orbit.

Sirius A has roughly twice the Sun’s mass and 1.7 times the Sun’s radius. Its estimated age is between 237 and 247 million years, which makes the star considerably younger than the Sun (4.6 billion years). Sirius A has a visual magnitude of -1.47 and an absolute magnitude of +1.42. Its estimated surface temperature is 9,940 K. Its projected rotational velocity is 16 km/s, not high enough to cause any marked flattening. 

Sirius A is a metallic-line star (Am star), with a spectrum that shows strong absorption lines of elements heavier than helium. It has 316% of the Sun’s abundance of iron. The star’s spectral type, A0mA1 Va, indicates that Sirius A would have the classification A1 based on its hydrogen and helium lines, but it would belong to the spectral class A0 based on the absorption lines of metals. The high content of metals is believed to be mainly present in the surface layers, not in the entire star.

Sirius B, on the other hand, is considerably smaller and fainter, and yet it is one of the more massive white dwarfs ever discovered. It has an apparent magnitude of 8.44 and an absolute magnitude of 11.18. Its mass is only slightly greater than the Sun’s (1.018 solar masses) and its radius is only 0.0084 solar radii. In other words, it has the mass of a Sun packed into the size of the Earth. The star’s estimated surface temperature is about 25,200 K and it will continue to gradually decrease over the next 2 billion years. The estimated age of Sirius B is 228 million years. The star is a stronger source of X-ray radiation than Sirius A.

fields.name: Tabby
fields.description:
Tabby is an F-type main-sequence star in the constellation Cygnus approximately 1,470 light-years from Earth. Unusual light fluctuations of Tabby's Star, including up to a 22% dimming in brightness, were discovered by citizen scientists as part of the Planet Hunters project. The discovery was made from data collected by the Kepler space telescope, which observed changes in the brightness of distant stars to detect exoplanets. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the star's large irregular changes in brightness, but none to date fully explain all aspects of the curve. Tabby has the stellar classification F3 V. Observations of the luminosity of the star by the Kepler space telescope show small, frequent, non-periodic dips in brightness, along with two large recorded dips in brightness two years apart. The amplitude of the changes in the star's brightness, and the aperiodicity of the changes, mean that this star is of particular interest for astronomers. The star's changes in brightness are consistent with many small masses orbiting the star in "tight formation".

Tabby's Star Radius isn't that much bigger than The Sun at 1.58. It may seem bigger but compared to other stars out there, its tiny. Tabby's Star mass is 1.43 times that of our star and will meet the same death as our star when the time comes, it will die as a white dwarf but first will be surrounded by a Planetary Nebula as it looses its mass in stellar winds.

fields.name: Vega
fields.description:
Vega is a bright white main sequence star located 25.04 light-years from Earth in the northern constellation Lyra. Vega has the spectral classification A0V, indicating a white star on the main sequence, still fusing hydrogen into helium in its core. The star has a mass of 2.135 solar masses and a radius between 2.362 and 2.818 times that of the Sun. With a surface temperature of 9,602 K, it shines with 40.12 solar luminosities. Vega is a relatively young star, with an estimated age of about 455 million years. Even though Vega is only about a tenth the age of the Sun, having twice the Sun’s mass means that it will live only a tenth of the Sun’s lifetime. These days, Vega is close to the midpoint of its life cycle. It will become an M-type red giant in about 500 million years, after it stops fusing hydrogen in its core. Eventually, the bright star will lose most of its mass and end its life as a white dwarf. In the late red giant stage, it will cast away its outer gaseous envelope to form a planetary nebula. The clouds of gas ejected from the star will glow until they dissipate into the surrounding space and the dense stellar remnant will gradually cool and fade. 

Vega completes a full rotation around its axis every 12.5 hours. For comparison, the Sun takes just over 25 days even though it is considerably smaller. Vega spins with an exceptionally high rotational velocity – estimates are as high as 236.2 ± 3.7 km/s along the equator – and, as a result, it is flattened at the poles and has an extended equator. The high spin rate gives Vega the shape of an oblate spheroid. The star’s equatorial diameter is 19% larger than its polar diameter. Vega’s equatorial bulge cannot be observed directly because we only get a pole-on view.

fields.name: Zeta Ophiuchi
fields.description:
Zeta Ophiuchi is a hot blue subgiant star located 366 light-years away in the constellation Ophiuchus. Zeta Ophiuchi is the nearest O-type star to the Sun. It is one of the bright stars that outline the polygonal constellation figure of the celestial Serpent Bearer. Zeta Ophiuchi is a massive blue subgiant star of the spectral type O9.2 IVnn. Some sources give it the stellar classification O9.5 V, indicating a hydrogen-fusing dwarf. Its mass of 20.2 solar masses determines its ultimate fate as a supernova. The star has a radius 8.5 times that of the Sun and is 74,100 times more luminous than our star, with an effective temperature of about 34,300 K. It has an estimated age of only 3 million years.

Even though it is still young, the hot star will expand into a red supergiant in the next few million years. When it does, its diameter will be greater than the orbit of Jupiter. The star will meet its end as a bright supernova, leaving behind a neutron star or pulsar. Zeta Ophiuchi is an exceptionally fast spinner, with a projected rotational velocity of up to 400 km/s. If it really spins this close to its breakup velocity, it takes a day to complete a rotation. Like most massive stars, Zeta Ophiuchi is losing mass through a powerful stellar wind that blows at about 1,600 km/s.

Zeta Ophiuchi is the nearest O-type star to Earth, as well as the brightest star in this spectral class, located in a dust-rich region of the Milky Way. Zeta Ophiuchi is located in the constellation Ophiuchus. Ophiuchus is the 11th largest constellation in the sky. It stretches across an area of 948 square degrees. It is one of the 15 equatorial constellations, visible from most locations on Earth for at least part of the year.

fields.name: Homestar Pro Original home planetarium
fields.description:
Imagine enjoying the sky full of stars while sitting on your sofa. This dream can become reality with the Homestar Original from Sega Toys. Matataki is the first Sega Homestar Planetarium which lets the stars twinkle softly while projecting an authentic heaven view into your room. This creates a 3D image effect while projecting the stars at the same time. Matataki has built-in speakers with natural sounds from the sea and the mountains. Enjoy a perfect and romantic vision of the night sky. Fall asleep under twinkling stars with the timer on. While following the original Sega Homestar Planet design the Matataki has its own fresh appearance.

Since the product launch of the Sega Toys Homestar Original in 2006 it has established itslf as a leading brand. The Homestar Series was developed by the Japanese inventor & entrepreneur Takayuki Ohira. As a recognized specialist for professional planetariums he has received numerous innovation prizes. His company supplies large planetariums internationally. Ohira has been driving the development of the Sega Homestar series in the joint development efforts of both companies. The result is home planetariums which project thousands of stars also at home at a very fair price.

Technical specifications

  • 10,000 twinkling stars or 60,000 solid stars
  • Ultra-bright white LED with the power of 3 watt
  • Speaker with natural sounds for deep sleep
  • Shooting star
  • USB cable enabling wall plug or wall plug free power bank operation
  • Projecting diameter of 106 in
  • Original Japanese packaging gift box

Twinkling is made possible by adding a second disc, the effect plate, under a special star disc. Next you turn on the diurnal motion (rotation) function. After starting the projection your eyes and mind will relax and focus. After a short time, you will see the realistic twinkling effect as if you are watching the stars in the universe from planet earth. This effect gives the projection more depth (3D).

fields.name: Astro Planetarium - Multimedia
fields.description:
Having your own home planetarium no longer needs to be a pipe dream! With the Astro Planetarium, you can project the night sky directly on to your ceiling - and have it accurate to the day and time! Furthermore, thanks to an integrated motor, it is possible for shooting stars to pass by. Suitable musical accompaniment is provided either by the inbuilt FM radio or the option to connect your MP3 player.

Technical specifications

  • Projection surface: approx. 1.6m x 2.2m (from 2m away)
  • Output power (lumens): 190lm (for 2m high ceilings)
  • Slides: 2 pieces (stars, constellations)
  • Integrated radio function and loudspeaker
  • Option to connect MP3 player
  • Sturdy stand

fields.name: Planetarium LabZZ SP50 UFO
fields.description:
The Levenhuk LabZZ SP50 UFO is a compact planetarium designed in the shape of a flying saucer with LED lighting and remote control. It includes space-themed projection films. Its large projection area covers 30m². You can select the rotation mode as well as adjust its speed and direction. Depending on the lighting in the room you decide on the brightness level. The LEDs have two modes of operation: single color and multicolor.

It is optimal to place the planetarium at a distance of 2–2.5m from the ceiling or other surface on which the image will be projected. The device comes with a 1.8m USB cable and an adapter to power the projector from the power supply. The remote control is powered by batteries. You can adjust the image sharpness manually by rotating the focusing wheel. You can leave the projector on before going to bed by simply setting the auto-off time (45 or 90 minutes).

Technical specifications

  • Projection distance: 200 cm to 250 cm
  • 3 brightness levels 3 rotation speeds option to select the direction of rotation
  • Color LEDs for creating ambient light
  • Remote control
  • 6 projection films
  • Light source power 10W

fields.name: Shoot the Moon
fields.description:
Shoot the Moon will be an instant hit in your house or office! This classic 1940’s nostalgia game is hilariously addictive, fun and challenging. The object of the game is to balance the ball on the metal track to score points in corresponding wells. Mercury, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, and Pluto signify score zones. Seems simple enough right? See for yourself why people go crazy for this game.

Ages 9+

fields.name: Space-opoly
fields.description:
Get lost in space. Collect your favorite cosmic wonders and play to rule the universe. Watch out for the black hole or you won't be home in time for dinner.

Ages 8+

  • For 2-6 players
  • Traditional play or one-hour version
  • Great family fun
  • Package dimension : 15.375" L x 10.625" W x 2.0625" H

fields.name: NASA Space Shuttle Discovery
fields.description:
The most outstanding feature of this Shuttle Discovery model kit is its authentic details. Open the payload bay to deploy the Hubble Telescope on its mission to explore the cosmos. Adjust the elevons, engage the landing gear on reentry and deploy the robotic arm. These details help to make the model look like the real-life Space Shuttle, making it a great addition to any collection or display. This detail-filled space shuttle model comes with a display stand and is an eye-catching centerpiece for the home or office. It's the best gift for adults and older kids who love creative projects. Enjoy hours of immersive building, perfect for experienced and beginner model builders alike, it's a must-have for anyone interested in space exploration and the history of NASA.

Ages 8+

About:

  • Theme Building
  • Package dimension : 19.3"L x 12.2"W

fields.name: Planet Doku
fields.description:
Each set has three levels of puzzles to challenge your Sudoku skills. By using planet and sun tokens instead of numbers, a solar system is created while playing each game.

This visually stunning version of Soduku adds an exciting twist to a classic game.

Ages 9+

fields.name: SpaceX Falcon 9
fields.description:
The Space X Falcon 9 is the world’s first human-rated, reusable launch vehicle. This scale model rocket can lift payloads to LEO and geosynchronous orbits, or even to Mars. There’s nothing else like it in the world! And now Estes and Space X have collaborated to create a highly accurate 1:100 scale flying model of the remarkable Falcon 9 rocket topped with a Dragon Crew spacecraft. Looks great on its custom display stand or soaring up to 300 feet on a recommended Estes engine.

About:

  • Precision 1:100 scale reproduction
  • Detailed Dragon Crew Spacecraft
  • Accurate silkscreened markings
  • Custom Display Stand
  • Removable plastic fins for stable flight
  • Large 24 in. parachute

fields.name: Haynes NASA Moon Missions Operations Manual
fields.description:
Author: Dr. David Baker
Originally published to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the first Moon landing by Apollo 11. While the original Apollo 11 mission is a great tale, this book dives deeper than other guides with an in-depth look at all of NASA’s lunar missions! An overview of the innovations, technology, political pressure, and more behind the Moon landings that are a testament to the bold vision NASA has maintained since first launching in 1958. All this information is formatted as an operations manual in an instructional manner so convincing you might just think you’ve been on an Apollo Moon mission yourself, yet digestible enough for any layperson to understand.
Author Dr. David Baker worked with NASA on three different programs over the course of 25 years and has written over 100 books on space flight. This expertise and inside knowledge paired with countless photographs, diagrams, illustrations, and more result in an outstandingly thorough guide.
Space enthusiasts, NASA fans, and anyone who loves to learn will appreciate this Haynes operations manual that highlights the advancements of the legendary agency that has pioneered Moon exploration for over 50 years.

Size: 8.5x11
Pages: 220

fields.name: Observing Nebulae
fields.description:
Author: Mark Griffiths

Nebulae, or ethereal clouds of gas and dust, are some of the most beautiful objects in the sky. By using a telescope, one can observe or even photograph nebulae from their own home.

This guide offers a non-mathematical approach to the subject that is easy for anyone to follow. Details of some of the brightest and best nebulae are outlined as well as some challenges for the more experienced observers. Photographs of each object to help with identification and celestial coordinates are outlined to help locate nebulae in the night sky.

Size: "6.1" x 9.2"
Pages: 289

fields.name: 3D Galaxy Crystal Ball
fields.description: LED base can be powered by USB or battery (product does not contain batteries), so that you can send the gift can be light up again at any time and place, stunning brilliant colorful lights, will make him fascinated and like the gift you send, it can be placed in the dresser, living room, work desk, bedroom, fireplace to bring a sense of ritual to life.

fields.name: Ceramic Coffee Mug Tea Cup
fields.description: The coffee mug cup is made of ceramic and not your ordinary coffee mug. You will definitely like the feel of the mug in your hands as it is sturdy but had a wonderful shape to fit comfortably wrap your hands around it and it holds a perfect amount of tea coffee of more than 11 OZ.

fields.name: Visual Galaxy
fields.description:
Visual Galaxy: The Ultimate Guide to the Milky Way and Beyond
Publisher‏: National Geographic; Illustrated edition (October 22, 2019)

This compelling visual journey through our galaxy combines more than 350 photographs, illustrations, and graphics to present the universe as you've never seen it before.
Visual Galaxy is a deep dive into the past, present, and future of our home galaxy, the Milky Way. In this mind-expanding visual tour through the cosmos, spectacular photographs are converted into interpretive graphics, starting with the sun and moving outward into space where stars are born, black holes lurk, and planets of diverse size and anatomy spin through their orbit. The final chapters locate our galaxy within the known universe and add a scintillating peek of other exoplanets in the cosmos. Detailed maps and fascinating imagery from recent space missions are paired with clear, authoritative scientific information.

Size: 9.23 x 1.09 x 11.58
Pages: 324

fields.name: Galaxy Projector
fields.description:
Experience the cosmos in stunning detail with our next-generation high-transparency optical lens. Boasting an industrial-grade 2-million pixel lens with an incredible 95% light transmission rate, it reveals the night sky's every nuance. The 5K Ultra HD disc lens, meticulously etched using cutting-edge photolithography, brings the universe right before your eyes.

Dive into an array of disc series sets, from constellations and starry skies to the Milky Way and planetary discs. This lamp allows you to experience the awe-inspiring beauty of the galaxy. Plus, we've curated exclusive disc sets for kids to spark their curiosity and exploration of the universe. We're continuing to design more fun discs!

POCOCO Galaxy Projector + Realistic Constellation-1

  • Included Components: Projector×1, Disc (Diamond Stars) × 1, Usb-c charging cable × 1(No Charger), Blank postcards and user manual posters ×1, , An extra disc (Westerlund2) as a gift

fields.name: JUNIOR Astro Planetarium
fields.description:
The BRESSER JUNIOR Astro Planetarium quickly transforms your ceiling into a starry sky. And then it’s time for you to go exploring: This home planetarium projects over 8,000 stars and 61 named constellations using 2 projection discs and a bright LED, bringing the universe into your home. Ever curious about the constellations visible on your birthday? Why not have a look? Just set the date and a time between 8 PM and 2 AM, because during this time there will always be stars in the sky. Then just switch on the children's planetarium and the night sky of your birthday lights up above you. For the best experience, maintain a 2-meter distance from the ceiling. This allows the projection to cover a substantial area of approximately 1.6 x 2.1 metres. A focusing wheel ensures the celestial display is crystal clear. This is not just for special occasions like Christmas or birthdays; it's a year-round gateway to the stars.

Technical specifications

  • Star projector suitable for children aged 14 and up
  • Shooting star function
  • Automatic shut-off (after 30, 60, or 120 minutes)
  • Projection area of 1.6 x 2.1 metres (at a 2-metre distance)
  • 1 bright, white LED
  • Motion-enabled projection through dual motors offering 6 speeds
  • Focusing wheel for clear images
  • Night sky simulation on walls or ceilings, adjustable for specific dates and times
  • More than 8,000 celestial bodies and 61 constellations on 2 projection discs
  • Maximum projection distance: 3 metres
